claim: A square is always a rectangle

supporting.text: A square meets the definition of a rectangle as it has four right angles and opposite sides that are equal and parallel.

attacks.text: A square meets the definition of a rectangle as it has four right angles and opposite sides that are equal and parallel.
While a square is a type of rectangle, the claim implies that all rectangles are squares, which is incorrect.
The claim states 'A square is always a rectangle,' which is true and does not imply that all rectangles are squares.
In some non-Euclidean geometries, the properties of squares and rectangles may not hold, making the claim context-dependent.
Standard Euclidean geometry is the common framework for such definitions, making non-Euclidean cases irrelevant for most practical purposes.

supporting.text: All properties of a rectangle (four sides, four right angles, opposite sides equal and parallel) are satisfied by a square.

attacks.text: All properties of a rectangle (four sides, four right angles, opposite sides equal and parallel) are satisfied by a square.
A square has additional constraints (all sides equal) not required by a rectangle, making it a special case rather than a general rectangle.
Mathematically, a square is a subset of rectangles, meaning all squares are rectangles by definition, even if they have stricter properties.
In informal contexts, people often distinguish squares from rectangles, implying they are not the same.
Mathematical definitions override informal usage, and in formal geometry, squares are explicitly classified as rectangles.

supporting.text: In geometry, a square is classified as a special case of a rectangle where all four sides are of equal length.

attacks.text: In geometry, a square is classified as a special case of a rectangle where all four sides are of equal length.

A square requires all angles to be 90 degrees and all sides equal, whereas a rectangle only requires angles to be 90 degrees and opposite sides equal. Thus, not all rectangles meet the criteria of a square.
The definition of a rectangle includes all quadrilaterals with four right angles, which inherently includes squares as a subset where sides are additionally equal.
Common usage sometimes distinguishes squares from rectangles in non-technical contexts, leading to potential confusion.
Mathematical definitions are precise and do not depend on colloquial usage; in formal geometry, squares are unequivocally a subset of rectangles.

supporting.text: The inclusive definition of a rectangle in mathematics explicitly includes squares as a subset of rectangles.

attacks.text: The inclusive definition of a rectangle in mathematics explicitly includes squares as a subset of rectangles.
In some informal contexts, 'rectangle' is used exclusively to refer to non-square rectangles, creating ambiguity.
Mathematical definitions are standardized and context-independent, so informal usage does not override the formal definition.
The properties of squares (equal sides) are more restrictive than general rectangles, making them a special case rather than a default example.
Special cases are still valid instances under the broader definition, so this does not contradict the claim.

supporting.text: Every square can be considered a rectangle because it adheres to the same geometric axioms and theorems that define rectangles.

attacks.text: Every square can be considered a rectangle because it adheres to the same geometric axioms and theorems that define rectangles.
A square is a special case of a rectangle with additional constraints (all sides equal), so it is not accurate to say it is 'always' a rectangle without acknowledging its specificity.
The definition of a rectangle includes quadrilaterals with four right angles, and squares meet this definition, so they are indeed rectangles by default.
In some contexts, distinguishing squares from general rectangles is necessary for precision, which may lead to treating them separately despite the inclusive definition.

supporting.text: The hierarchical classification of quadrilaterals in geometry places squares within the category of rectangles due to shared properties.

attacks.text: The hierarchical classification of quadrilaterals in geometry places squares within the category of rectangles due to shared properties.
Some definitions of rectangles require opposite sides to be equal but do not explicitly require all angles to be 90 degrees, which could exclude squares.
Standard geometric definitions universally require rectangles to have four right angles, making squares a subset by definition.
In non-Euclidean geometries, the properties of quadrilaterals can differ, potentially breaking the square-rectangle hierarchy.
Euclidean geometry is the standard framework for such classifications, and non-Euclidean cases are edge exceptions.
